entry.et: Middle English, from Old English lēoht; akin to Old High German lioht light, Latin luc-, lux light, lucēre to shine, Greek leukos white

def.dt: :the sensation aroused by stimulation of the visual receptors
:electromagnetic radiation of any wavelength that travels in a vacuum with a speed of about 186,281 miles (300,000 kilometers) per second
:such radiation that is visible to the human eye
:a particular aspect or appearance presented to view saw the matter in a different light
:something that enlightens or informs shed some light on the problem
:a medium (as a window) through which light is admitted
:a set of principles, standards, or opinions worship according to one's lights Adrienne Koch
:a noteworthy person in a particular place or field a leading light among current writers
:a flame for lighting something (as a cigarette)
:in view of in light of their findings, new procedures were established
:not dark, intense, or swarthy in color or coloring :pale
:medium in saturation and high in lightness light blue
:to become light :brighten usually used with up her face lit up
:to ignite something (as a cigarette) often used with up
:animate brighten a smile lit up her face

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English lēoht; akin to Old High German līhti light, Latin levis, Greek elachys small

def.dt: :designed to carry a comparatively small load a light truck
:having relatively little weight in proportion to bulk aluminum is a light metal
:containing less than the legal, standard, or usual weight a light coin
:not abundant light rain a light lunch
:exerting a minimum of force or pressure :gentle a light touch
:resulting from a very slight pressure :faint light print
:capable of moving swiftly or nimbly light on his feet
:less powerful but usually more mobile than usual for its kind light cavalry a light cruiser
:made with a lower calorie content or with less of some ingredient (as salt, fat, or alcohol) than usual
:coarse and sandy or easily pulverized light soil
:dizzy giddy felt light in the head
:intended chiefly to entertain light verse light comedy
:carrying little or no cargo the ship returned light
:producing goods for direct consumption by the consumer light industry
:not bearing a stress or accent a light syllable
:having a clear soft quality a light voice
:being in debt to the pot in a poker game three chips light

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English līhtan; akin to Old English lēoht light in weight

def.dt: :settle alight a bird lit on the lawn
:to fall unexpectedly usually used with on or upon
:to arrive by chance :happen usually used with on or upon lit upon a solution
:to attack forcefully I lit into that food until I'd finished off the heel of the loaf Helen Eustis
:diminished or lacking in substance or seriousness lite news
:being an innocuous or unthreatening version often used postpositively it is film noir lite James Greenberg
:the process including contraction of the pupil and decrease in rhodopsin by which the eye adapts to conditions of increased illumination
:wind having a speed of 1 to 3 miles (about 1 to 5 kilometers) per hour see beaufort scale table
